channel.title: Agh, DDoS
channel.description:
I'm running a Linux server with Ubuntu 11.04.
My server is currently being DDoSed on port 80 (TCP). When I block the port with iptables, the effects of the DDoS stop for other services hosted on the machine, however I've found that there are thousands of addresses that are connecting to my server causing this to happen. With that said, adding them to iptables is not an option.
I need to find an application or a method to throttle the connections. Thanks, - Coelho

item.title: Agh, DDoS
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

[quote=“Dr Troll, post:2, topic:421317”][quote author=Coelho link=topic=523963.msg3812608#msg3812608 date=1321061546]

this is laughable, have you no firewall on your server?

It is a clean ubuntu install with nginx and some other services running on it. The only firewall I have is iptables, which has no drop rules.

I’ve never felt the need to add more protection until now.
[/quote]
hmm, mabey you should add another one mabey upgrade your protection? just a… derp… suggestion[/quote]
If you read the op, you would know I am asking for a suggestion for an application that will fix or minimalize my problem. This implies I do not know what application will accomplish this. Your comment is unhelpful.

Read full topic

item.title: Agh, DDoS
item.dc:creator: @krackkid Krackkid
item.description:
@krackkid wrote:

Now you’re gonna have a baby

Read full topic

item.title: Agh, DDoS
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

this is laughable, have you no firewall on your server?

It is a clean ubuntu install with nginx and some other services running on it. The only firewall I have is iptables, which has no drop rules.

I’ve never felt the need to add more protection until now.

Read full topic

item.title: Agh, DDoS
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

I managed to throttle the DDoS enough for it to not have any adverse effects on the server using

iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --syn --dport 80 -m connlimit --connlimit-above 5 -j DROP
Edit: Nevermind! I'm getting 400 ping to the server, and the server can barely request. It couldn't be more noticeable.

Read full topic

item.title: Agh, DDoS
item.dc:creator: @Kozs Kozs
item.description:
@Kozs wrote:

[quote=“Coelho, post:4, topic:421299”][quote author=krackkid link=topic=523963.msg3812361#msg3812361 date=1321052854]
I don’t think half the people who claim to be getting DDoS are actually getting DDoS
[/quote]
I have already checked the incoming connections, and this is not normal. Not to mention, my nginx logs can tell me further.

There are 22 “access.log” archives (which is what nginx does when the log file is too large). Domain’s are given their own file such as “domain.com.access.log”, so they should not ever be writing to the default “access.log”. The only host that writes to “access.log” is my external ip. Now what normal user will connect to my external ip so much as to generate 22 archives.

I am sure this is intentional DDoS.[/quote]

Pm server details I will go on and try to help issue

Read full topic

item.title: Agh, DDoS
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

krackkid:

I don’t think half the people who claim to be getting DDoS are actually getting DDoS

I have already checked the incoming connections, and this is not normal. Not to mention, my nginx logs can tell me further.

There are 22 “access.log” archives (which is what nginx does when the log file is too large). Domain’s are given their own file such as “domain.com.access.log”, so they should not ever be writing to the default “access.log”. The only host that writes to “access.log” is my external ip. Now what normal user will connect to my external ip so much as to generate 22 archives.

I am sure this is intentional DDoS.

Read full topic
